Calculate changes in internal energy for ideal gases and other systems
Apply the First Law to cyclic processes and heat engines
Solve complex problems involving multiple energy transfers

classifications.note: First Law: ΔU = Q - W or ΔU = Q + W (sign convention dependent), Internal energy U: sum of all microscopic energies, Heat Q: energy transfer due to ΔT, Work W: energy transfer by mechanical means, Sign convention: Q > 0 heat into system, W > 0 work done by system

principles.principle: First Law Fundamentals and Internal Energy
principles.statement: The First Law of Thermodynamics establishes energy conservation for thermal systems: First Law Statement: ΔU = Q - W; ΔU = change in internal energy; Q = heat added to system; W = work done by system. Alternative Convention: ΔU = Q + W (W = work done on system); Must be consistent with sign convention; Physics typically uses ΔU = Q - W. Internal Energy (U): Total energy contained within system; Sum of kinetic and potential energies of all molecules; For ideal gases: U depends only on temperature; U = (f/2)nRT where f = degrees of freedom. Heat Transfer (Q): Energy transfer due to temperature difference; Not a state function (path dependent); Positive when into system; Mechanisms: conduction, convection, radiation. Work (W): Energy transfer by mechanical means; W = ∫P dV for pressure-volume work; Path dependent; Positive when done by system. Sign Conventions: Q > 0: heat into system; Q < 0: heat out of system; W > 0: work done by system; W < 0: work done on system; ΔU > 0: internal energy increases. State Functions vs Path Functions: State functions: U, P, V, T (depend only on state); Path functions: Q, W (depend on process path); ΔU path-independent, Q and W path-dependent. Microscopic Interpretation: Internal energy includes: translational, rotational, vibrational kinetic energy; Intermolecular potential energy; Chemical bond energy; Nuclear energy.
principles.application: Apply First Law to calculate unknown quantities. Determine internal energy changes. Calculate work from P-V diagrams. Analyze heat transfer in processes. Use appropriate sign conventions. Distinguish between state and path functions.
principles.example: Calculate work done in gas expansion. Determine heat transfer given internal energy change. Analyze energy conservation in thermal process.
principles.analogy: Like a bank account where internal energy is your balance, heat transfer is deposits, and work is withdrawals - the change in your balance (ΔU) equals deposits (Q) minus withdrawals (W), with the exact path of deposits and withdrawals affecting the individual amounts but not the net balance change

worked_examples.title: Basic First Law Application
worked_examples.problem: A system absorbs 500 J of heat and does 300 J of work on its surroundings. Calculate the change in internal energy.

step_by_step.explanation: Q = +500 J (heat into system), W = +300 J (work done by system)
Internal energy increases by 200 J; System gains net energy
Energy in (500 J) = Energy out (300 J work) + Energy stored (200 J ΔU)

worked_examples.final_answer: ΔU = +200 J; Internal energy increases by 200 J; Energy conserved in process

image.caption: Basic First Law of Thermodynamics application

worked_examples.title: Work Calculation from P-V Diagram
worked_examples.problem: A gas expands from 2 L to 5 L at constant pressure 3 atm. Calculate work done.

step_by_step.explanation: W = PΔV = 3 atm × (5 - 2) L = 9 L·atm; 9 L·atm × 101.325 J/L·atm = 911.9 J

worked_examples.final_answer: Work done = 912 J; Positive work indicates system does work on surroundings during expansion

sections.introduction: Analyzing specific thermodynamic processes including isothermal, adiabatic, isobaric, and isochoric processes, and their representation on pressure-volume diagrams.

key_concept.definition: Isothermal process, Adiabatic process, Isobaric process, Isochoric process, P-V diagrams, Process work, Heat transfer in processes
key_concept.context: Different thermodynamic processes have characteristic relationships between pressure, volume, and temperature, with specific work and heat transfer behaviors that can be visualized on P-V diagrams.

classifications.value: Classification based on constant parameters and energy transfer
classifications.behavior: Different thermodynamic processes exhibit characteristic behaviors: isothermal processes maintain constant temperature with specific P-V relationship, adiabatic processes involve no heat transfer, isobaric processes occur at constant pressure, isochoric processes have constant volume with no work done

examples.explanation: Interpreting work, heat transfer, and internal energy changes from P-V diagrams

examples.explanation: Calculating work done in different thermodynamic processes

classifications.note: Isothermal: T constant, PV = constant, Adiabatic: Q = 0, PV^γ = constant, Isobaric: P constant, W = PΔV, Isochoric: V constant, W = 0, Work = area under P-V curve, Direction determines work sign

principles.statement: Different thermodynamic processes have characteristic behaviors and representations: Isothermal Process: Constant temperature (ΔT = 0); For ideal gas: ΔU = 0, so Q = W; PV = constant (Boyle's Law); Work: W = nRT ln(V₂/V₁); Slow process to maintain temperature equilibrium. Adiabatic Process: No heat transfer (Q = 0); ΔU = -W; PV^γ = constant, where γ = C_p/C_v; Temperature changes during process; Fast process or good insulation. Isobaric Process: Constant pressure (ΔP = 0); Work: W = PΔV; Common in open systems; Heat transfer: Q = nC_pΔT. Isochoric Process: Constant volume (ΔV = 0); No work (W = 0); ΔU = Q; Heat transfer: Q = nC_vΔT; Pressure changes with temperature. P-V Diagrams: Pressure vs volume plots; Work = area under curve; Clockwise cycles: net work done by system; Counterclockwise: net work on system. Polytropic Processes: General process: PV^n = constant; n = 0: isobaric; n = 1: isothermal; n = γ: adiabatic; n = ∞: isochoric. Cyclic Processes: System returns to initial state; ΔU = 0 for complete cycle; Q_net = W_net; Heat engines and refrigerators. Process Combinations: Real processes often combinations; Must analyze step by step; Internal energy change depends only on initial and final states.
principles.application: Identify process type from given conditions. Calculate work from P-V diagrams. Determine heat transfer in specific processes. Analyze energy transfers in cyclic processes. Use appropriate equations for each process type. Interpret P-V diagram features.
principles.example: Calculate work in isothermal expansion. Determine final temperature in adiabatic compression. Analyze complete cycle on P-V diagram.
principles.analogy: Like different exercise routines on a fitness machine - isothermal is like maintaining constant effort while moving (constant T), adiabatic is like quick bursts with no rest (no heat exchange), isobaric is like pushing against constant resistance (constant P), and isochoric is like isometric exercise with no movement (constant V), with the total 'workout' (energy transfer) depending on the routine chosen

worked_examples.title: Isothermal Expansion Work
worked_examples.problem: 2.0 moles of ideal gas expand isothermally at 300 K from 1.0 L to 3.0 L. Calculate work done and heat transfer.

step_by_step.explanation: Isothermal: constant temperature, ΔU = 0 for ideal gas
ΔU = 0 = Q - W, so Q = W = 5479 J
Work positive (system does work), heat positive (heat absorbed); All heat converted to work in isothermal expansion

worked_examples.final_answer: Work done = 5479 J; Heat transfer = 5479 J; In isothermal expansion, all heat absorbed becomes work done

worked_examples.title: Adiabatic Compression
worked_examples.problem: A monatomic ideal gas (γ = 5/3) is compressed adiabatically to half its volume. Initial temperature 300 K. Find final temperature and work done per mole.

step_by_step.explanation: Adiabatic: Q = 0, so ΔU = -W; For monatomic gas: ΔU = (3/2)nRΔT
W negative: work done on system; Temperature increases due to compression work

worked_examples.final_answer: Final temperature = 476 K; Work done on gas = 2195 J/mol; Adiabatic compression increases temperature significantly

sections.introduction: Applying the First Law to practical systems including heat engines, refrigerators, biological systems, and everyday thermodynamic processes.

key_concept.definition: Heat engines, Refrigerators, Heat pumps, Thermal efficiency, Coefficient of performance, Biological energy, Practical applications
key_concept.context: The First Law of Thermodynamics finds extensive applications in energy conversion systems, refrigeration technology, biological processes, and understanding everyday thermal phenomena.

image.caption: Heat engines and practical applications of First Law

classifications.value: Classification based on system function and energy flow direction
characteristics: Refrigerators (move heat from cold to hot)
classifications.behavior: Different energy conversion systems have characteristic operating principles: heat engines absorb heat from hot reservoir, reject heat to cold reservoir, and produce work; refrigerators and heat pumps use work to move heat against natural flow; biological systems convert chemical energy to work and heat

examples.explanation: Analyzing efficiency and energy flows in heat engines
Analyzing performance of refrigerators and heat pumps

classifications.note: Heat engine: W = Q_H - Q_C, efficiency η = W/Q_H = 1 - Q_C/Q_H, Refrigerator: COP = Q_C/W, Heat pump: COP = Q_H/W, Biological systems: convert food energy to work and heat, Real systems have losses and irreversibilities

principles.statement: The First Law applies to various practical systems for energy conversion and transfer: Heat Engines: Convert heat to work; Operate in cycles; Absorb heat Q_H from hot reservoir; Reject heat Q_C to cold reservoir; Produce work W = Q_H - Q_C; Efficiency: η = W/Q_H = 1 - Q_C/Q_H. Refrigerators: Use work to move heat from cold to hot; Absorb heat Q_C from cold space; Reject heat Q_H to warm space; Require work input W; COP = Q_C/W (coefficient of performance). Heat Pumps: Move heat from cold outside to warm inside; Similar to refrigerator but different purpose; COP = Q_H/W; Typically COP > 1 (more heat moved than work input). Internal Combustion Engines: Otto cycle (gasoline engines); Diesel cycle; Convert chemical energy to work; Significant heat losses to exhaust and cooling. Steam Power Plants: Rankine cycle; Boiler, turbine, condenser, pump; High temperature difference improves efficiency; Combined cycle plants more efficient. Biological Applications: Human body: ~20% efficiency in converting food to work; Rest dissipated as heat; Basal metabolic rate; Thermoregulation; Muscle contraction. Everyday Applications: Cooking and food processing; Heating and cooling buildings; Automotive systems; Electronic device cooling; Atmospheric processes. Energy Conservation: First Law prevents perpetual motion machines of first kind; Energy accounting for complex systems; Environmental impact analysis; Renewable energy systems.
principles.application: Calculate heat engine efficiency. Determine refrigerator performance. Analyze energy flows in power plants. Apply First Law to biological systems. Calculate work requirements for heating/cooling. Design energy-efficient systems.
principles.example: Calculate efficiency of Carnot engine. Determine COP of refrigerator. Analyze human metabolic energy balance.
principles.analogy: Like a water wheel in a stream - a heat engine takes in 'high-grade' energy (heat from hot source), uses some to do work (turning the wheel), and rejects the 'low-grade' remaining energy (heat to cold sink), with the First Law ensuring all accounted for, while refrigerators work like water pumps moving water uphill against gravity

worked_examples.title: Heat Engine Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A heat engine absorbs 2000 J from a hot reservoir at 500 K and rejects 1200 J to a cold reservoir at 300 K. Calculate work output and efficiency.

step_by_step.explanation: Actual efficiency equals Carnot efficiency; Ideal performance
Energy in (2000 J) = Energy out (1200 J + 800 J); Conservation verified

worked_examples.final_answer: Work output = 800 J; Efficiency = 40%; Matches Carnot efficiency for given temperatures

worked_examples.title: Refrigerator Performance
worked_examples.problem: A refrigerator removes 500 J of heat from its cold compartment and requires 150 J of work. Calculate COP and heat rejected to room.

step_by_step.explanation: Energy in (150 J work + 500 J from cold) = Energy out (650 J to room)
COP > 1 means more heat moved than work input; Typical for refrigerators
Room receives more heat (650 J) than removed from refrigerator (500 J); Net heating effect

worked_examples.final_answer: COP = 3.33; Heat rejected = 650 J; Refrigerator moves 3.33× more heat than work input

common_misconceptions: Thinking heat and work are the same type of energy
Believing internal energy depends on process path
Thinking heat engines can be 100% efficient
Believing refrigerators create cold rather than move heat
Assuming work is only mechanical in thermodynamics
Thinking First Law allows perpetual motion machines
real_world_applications: Internal combustion engine design and analysis
summary: The First Law of Thermodynamics, expressed as ΔU = Q - W, represents energy conservation for thermal systems, stating that the change in internal energy of a system equals the heat added to the system minus the work done by the system. Internal energy (U) is a state function depending only on the system state, while heat (Q) and work (W) are path-dependent process functions. Different thermodynamic processes have characteristic behaviors: isothermal processes maintain constant temperature with ΔU = 0, adiabatic processes involve no heat transfer with ΔU = -W, isobaric processes occur at constant pressure, and isochoric processes have constant volume with W = 0. Work in thermodynamic processes can be calculated as the area under P-V curves, with cyclic processes having ΔU = 0 over complete cycles. Practical applications include heat engines that convert heat to work with efficiency η = W/Q_H, refrigerators that use work to move heat from cold to warm spaces with COP = Q_C/W, and heat pumps for building heating with COP = Q_H/W. The First Law finds applications across internal combustion engines, power plants, refrigeration systems, biological energy conversion, and environmental processes, providing the fundamental framework for analyzing energy transfers and conversions while preventing perpetual motion machines of the first kind through strict energy accounting.
